timeline.bodyText: Curious when this could be set - if the MQ is run in-process?

+package brave.messaging;
+
+import brave.Response;
+import brave.internal.Nullable;
+
+/**
+ * Abstract response type used for parsing and sampling of messaging clients and servers.
+ *
+ * @see ProducerResponse
+ * @see ConsumerResponse
+ * @since 5.13
+ */
+public abstract class MessagingResponse extends Response {
+  /**
+   * The request that initiated this messaging response or {@code null} if unknown.

replies.bodyText:
probably not the best sentence. So, for example the messageId field is only readable during the response processing of AWS SQS.
Different than RPC I think here it isn't important that the request is what initiated the response, rather it is simply the request data, available here so you can late process data like message Id
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: Ah I think it could be Information about the request that...
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText:
ps sometime around july last year we decided to replace message.X with messaging.X I don't recall the rationale but it should have been written down. I think it was to do with how the other properties would sound if prefixed "message" also to match the abstraction name.
The only reason I mention this is that we should decide if the tag name "messaging.id" is ok for the message id or we make "messaging.message_id" which is also awkward for the same. I don't have a strong feeling either way, but happy to add to the RATIONALE whatever we choose.
timeline.author: codefromthecrypt
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -59,13 +57,26 @@ /** * Messaging channel name, e.g. "hooks" or "complaints". {@code null} if unreadable. * - *

Conventionally associated with the key "messaging.channel_name"

replies.bodyText: Lean towards messaging.id since when in doubt, shorter seems better

timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -66,6 +66,23 @@ */ @Nullable public abstract String channelName(); + /** + * The possibly system generated value that uniquely identifies this message. Return {@code null} if + * the ID was unreadable or the transport has no canonical message ID format. + * + *

Examples: + * 

    
+   *   
  • Amazon SQS - "MessageId" response field. ex "5fea7756-0ea4-451a-a703-a558b933e274"
    • 
+   *   
  • JMS - "JMSMessageID" header. Ex "ID:10.77.42.209-4280-1477454185311-1:1:1391:1:1"
    • 
+   *   
  • RabbitMQ - AMQP "message-id" (max 256 char)

timeline.message:
Adds channelKind channelName and messageId properties

This adds three properties from #914, currently not discussing tag name
mapping.

* channelKind - string based enum "queue" or "topic"
* channelName - eg "hooks" or "complaints"
* messageId - ex value of JMSMessageId
prefer offset/sequence when no messageId field

Update instrumentation/messaging/RATIONALE.md

Co-authored-by: Jorge Esteban Quilcate Otoya <quilcate.jorge@gmail.com>
